title: 109_hr4967
content: The "Sunlight Act of 2006" is the short title of this Act. It includes a provision for the precertification of travel by the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. Clause 5 of rule XXV of the Rules of the House of Representatives is amended to require individuals to provide trip details and expenses to the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct before and after privately-funded trips. This information will be made available on the public website. The Committee on Standards of Official Conduct requires individuals to submit trip details and expenses for privately-funded trips before and after the trip. This information will be posted on the committee's public website for transparency. Members, Delegates, Resident Commissioners, officers, and employees of the House must comply with all applicable rules before taking a privately-funded trip. SEC. 3. DOLLAR AMOUNTS REQUIRED FOR ANNUAL FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE STATEMENTS. Financial disclosures for Members of Congress and officers and employees of Congress will now require exact dollar amounts for reporting categories. Additionally, reports filed under the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 will be made available to the public on the Internet in a searchable and sortable format. The amendment made by subsection (a) shall apply to reports filed for calendar years beginning after the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. PUBLIC DISPLAY OF DEBATES: Rule II of the House of Representatives is amended to require the Clerk to project the subject matter of debates on a wall during general debate. SEC. 5. AVAILABILITY OF LEGISLATIVE DOCUMENTS ONLINE: Bills, conference reports, and amendments must be available on the internet before voting. Rule XXI of the House of Representatives is amended to require bills, resolutions, and amendments to be available online for at least 48 hours before consideration. Amendments must be posted online immediately after being offered in a searchable format. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to mandate electronic filing for all reports, requiring each person to maintain and file reports in accessible electronic form. Designations, statements, and reports are now referred to as documents, and any report, designation, or statement must be filed electronically. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 now requires all reports to be filed electronically in a searchable and sortable format on the internet. The term "designation, statement, report, or notification" is replaced with "each report" for clarity. Software for filing reports electronically is also mandated. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require reports to be filed electronically in a searchable format. The term "designation, statement, report, or notification" is replaced with "each report" for clarity. Additionally, political committees must notify the appropriate authorities of all contributions made within 30 days of an election. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require electronic filing of reports in a searchable format. Political committees must notify authorities of contributions received within 30 days of an election, including candidate details, contributor identification, and contribution amount. Effective January 1, 2007, these amendments apply to reports for periods starting on or after that date.
